wikipedia_page.main: Colonel George Charles Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan, 1st Baron Bingham,  (13 December 1860 – 20 April 1949), styled with subsidiary, courtesy title Lord Bingham from 1888 to 1914, was a British soldier and Conservative politician. From 1920 until 1928 he was one of the King's aides-de-camp, a ceremonial honour awarded to military figures which entitles the recipient to wear the aiguillette, braided ropes.

link_mentions.page: Harold Alexander, 1st Earl Alexander of Tunis
response: Alexander married Lady Margaret Bingham, daughter of George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan, on 14 October 1931.  They had three children together and adopted a fourth:Mosley, Charles, editor. Burke's Peerage and Baronetage, 106th edition, 2 volumes. Crans, Switzerland: Burke's Peerage (Genealogical Books) Ltd, 1999.
|George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan||10 August 1914||Charles Bingham, 4th Earl of Lucan||20 April 1949

In 1803 Richard Bingham, 2nd Earl of Lucan bought the manor from William Lowther, 1st Earl of Lonsdale. Both Arnold and Lucan family names are prominent in All Saints' parish church, with memorials to various generations of those families. Lord Bingham, 3rd Earl of Lucan (1800–88), the Field Marshal who reluctantly passed on the order for the Charge of the Light Brigade at the Battle of Balaclava in 1854 is buried in the churchyard; along with Charles Bingham, 4th Earl of Lucan, George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan and their countesses. One of the village pubs was called the Lucan Arms pub for many years until it was renamed in the late 1990s.
*George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan (1860–1949), Conservative Chief Whip in the House of Lords (1929–1940)Harrow, 1800–1911, p. 501

link_mentions.page: George Charles Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan
Shane Alexander, 2nd Earl Alexander of Tunis
response: Alexander is the elder son of Field Marshal Harold Alexander, 1st Earl Alexander of Tunis and Lady Margaret Bingham (1905–1977), daughter of George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan. He was educated at Harrow and Ashbury College. He joined the Irish Guards in 1954. He succeeded his father in the earldom following his death on 16 June 1969.

| rowspan=2|Snell succeeded George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan. He was formerly Labour's leader in the House of Lords and died in office on 21 April 1944. The position remained unfilled until Fortescue's appointment in March 1945; he was previously a Lord-in-Waiting.
*George Bingham, 5th Earl of Lucan; MP for Chertsey (1904–1906)
